items.headline: US Stocks Steady Amid Cooling Inflation, AI Concerns Persist After Mixed Friday Session
items.summary: U.S. stocks showed a mixed performance on Friday, February 13, with major indices closing nearly flat after an encouraging update on inflation helped ease fears of aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes. However, underlying concerns about the potential downsides of the artificial intelligence (AI) boom continued to weigh on tech and related sectors, contributing to overall weekly declines for the major averages. Market sentiment remained cautious, with investors rotating out of some high-growth tech names.

items.headline: Coinbase Global Surges on Strong Performance
items.summary: Coinbase Global, Inc. ($COIN) was among the top gainers, soaring over 16% on Friday.

items.headline: Applied Materials Rises on AI-related Chip Investments
items.summary: Applied Materials, Inc. ($AMAT) saw an increase of over 8%, driven by accelerating investments in AI-related chip technology.

items.headline: Corsair Gaming Jumps on Q4 Beat
items.summary: Corsair Gaming ($CRSR) shares jumped over 54% after reporting a solid Q4 earnings beat and announcing a $50M share repurchase authorization.

items.headline: Constellation Brands Declines
items.summary: Constellation Brands, Inc. ($STZ) was a significant decliner, falling over 8% during Friday's trading.

items.headline: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Experiences Downturn
items.summary: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. ($NCLH) shares dropped more than 7.5% on Friday.

items.headline: Apple Shares Slip Amid Tech Selloff
items.summary: Apple ($AAPL) experienced a notable decline of 2.27% as the tech selloff continued, fueled by AI concerns.

items.headline: Sector Rotation: Utilities and Consumer Staples Lead, Tech and Financials Lag
items.summary: On Friday, defensive sectors such as Utilities (up 1.5%) and Consumer Staples (up 0.9%) demonstrated resilience. In contrast, Information Technology (-2.6%), Financials (-2.0%), and Communication Services (-1.8%) were among the worst performers, reflecting ongoing concerns about the artificial intelligence boom and its potential impact across industries. Eight out of eleven sectors of the S&P 500 ended in negative territory.

items.headline: Cooler January CPI Eases Rate Hike Fears; Q4 GDP Estimates Revised
items.summary: The U.S. Consumer Price Index (CPI) for January increased by 2.4% year-over-year and 0.2% month-over-month, both falling below market expectations. This encouraging inflation data helped to calm investor fears regarding potential Federal Reserve rate hikes. Looking ahead, the advance estimate for Q4 2025 GDP is expected to show annualized growth of around 2.8% to 3.0%, a moderation from the 4.4% seen in Q3.

items.headline: Fed Minutes and Upcoming Economic Data in Focus
items.summary: Investors are keenly awaiting the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, scheduled for release next Wednesday, February 18, to gain further insight into the central bank's policy outlook. The Fed held the federal funds rate steady at 3.50%â€“3.75% in January. Key upcoming economic releases include January industrial production, December trade figures, and weekly jobless claims.

items.headline: Major Earnings Reports: Wendy's and Cameco Announce Q4 Results, Retail Sector in Spotlight
items.summary: The Wendy's Company ($WEN) reported its Q4 2025 results, with global systemwide sales decreasing 8.3% but international sales growing 6.2%, and adjusted diluted EPS at $0.16. Cameco Corp. announced strong Q4 earnings of $199 million, beating analyst expectations with adjusted EPS of $0.50. Retail sector earnings are also a key focus, with Walmart ($WMT) and Target ($TGT) set to report soon, as Q4 earnings season progresses for the S&P 500.

items.headline: Macro Trend: AI Disruption and Market Volatility Remain Key Drivers
items.summary: Macroeconomic sentiment continues to be influenced by global trade dynamics and the transformative, yet disruptive, impact of artificial intelligence. While AI-related investments fuel business capital expenditure, concerns about its potential to upend traditional industries and impact profit margins are leading to significant market volatility, particularly in the tech sector. The US dollar has seen a gradual decline, and a softening labor market points to a cyclically sensitive juncture.
